bibl.title: Letter from James Carroll to Caroline Latimer, March 16, 1904

div1.p: Carroll presents his autobiography. He includes a note on immunity to yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from James Carroll to Caroline Latimer, March 16, 1904

opener.dateline:
WAR DEPARTMENT,
SURGEON GENERAL'S OFFICE,
ARMY MEDICAL MUSEUM AND LIBRARY,
WASHINGTON.
March 16th 1904.

div1.p:
Replying
to the interrogatories in
your letter of the 13th inst.
I trust the following will
afford the information
desired.

I was born at Woolwich,
England, June 5th 1854. --
Received a good common
school education and at 15
was attending a private school
preparatory to entering the
Navy as an engineer student.
-- My first course of lectures
in Medicine was taken at
the University of the City of New
York in the session of 1886-7.
My next opportunity was at
the University of Maryland in
the sessions of 1889-90 and 1890-
91. -- P. G. courses in Bacteriology
and Pathology during the winters
of 1891-2 and 1892-3 respectively.
(at the Johns Hopkins Hospital.)
-- was first associated with Dr
Reed when assigned to duty at
the Army Medical School at
Washington D.C., in October 1893.
Assisted him in studying the blood of vaccinated
calves, children and monkeys in the search for
Pfeiffer's supposed parasite. Assisted him also
in his work at Columbian University, which was
begun in 1896. In 1897 began, with him, the
study of B. icteroides, Sanarelli, and participated
in the yellow fever work throughout.

I entered the Army as a private in January 1874
and proceeded to Dakota in the summer of the
same year.

Additional information may be found in “who's who?”
and in “Men of Work in America.”
div1.closer:
Yours very truly, James Carroll.
AC
C to Dr.
P. S. (5). The bite of a contaminated mosquito
can only confer immunity from yellow fever when
it conveys the infection and the person actually bitten
actually suffers an attack of the disease. There is
not the slightest evidence to show that the bite of the
mosquito can confer immunity in any other way than through
an attack of the disease. See my paper on “The Transmission
of yellow Fever” read at the New Orleans meeting of the
Am. Med. Association in 1903.
J.C.
